Subject#1$2: Coal mining -- Colorado -- Las Animas County, CO
Subject#1$5: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: (no transcript available for this video interview) 10:00 -- discussing strikes by Wobblies and others 20:00 -- Cokedale changes from company town to private ownership 30:00 -- recalls parties in the coal camps 40:00 -- discusses gambling in Cokedale, years ago 50:00 -- compares life and costs today vs. during FDR's presidency ~1:04:00 -- videorecording ends
Description#2: This retired coal miner from Cokedale, Colorado discusses changes in the coal industry: area mines were busy in WWII, but shut down in 1947. As production wound down, the company was finding too much "sulphur" rock per load of coal. His dad died of "miner's consumption" (i.e. black lung). Wojtylka recalls many nationalities in Cokedale, including some Japanese miners when he was young. He also remembers an explosion in the mine. During a strike at Cokedale, scabs were beaten up by union members from out of town. (There had been less union organization at Cokedale, but more at Sopris and other nearby mines.) During the 1927 "Wobblies" strike (which in this area started at Valdez by the IWW), strikers scattered nails on the road. Cokedale coal mines had gotten union organization by 1943. The companies even provided bus transport to the coal mine. Wojtylka details conflicts between old-timers and newcomers to town. He served on the town council for quite a while; they organized town services after the company sold out. Cokedale is one of the few company towns that survived. Buildings sold for about $400 for a 4-room house. Over time, home heating has changed from coal to natural gas. Mining pay changed from script (when he was young) to gold to cash to checks. There were a few thefts of payroll from the company. In the coal camps, people seemed to enjoy life more than neighbors in cities or on farms. Neighbors often got together for parties and seemed able to get by, with less money. Wojtylka feels that today's workers expect more for less effort and are not willing to work. Mining camps were less isolated than ranches and farms, and also had shorter work-days. Working conditions in the mines were much better if it wasn't low coal. During Prohibition, some families made wine at home; there were a few bootleggers of whisky, also. There was even some gambling in Cokedale, many years ago. They used to enjoy streetcar service from Cokedale to Trinidad. Today, Wojtylka decries high prices and wages; he feels that people are unwilling to work for a good life. He compares life and costs today vs. during Roosevelt's presidency. Wojtylka admits that small towns such as Cokedale have governance problems because people are in conflict with each other. There's a surprising amount of conflict in such a small town: witness their difficulties finishing the local sewer service.
Editing notes#1: JZ: no transcript yet found for this video; 27 Mar. 2014

Subject#1$3: Coal mines and mining -- Las Animas County -- Colorado
Subject#1$2: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: Mrs. Emma Zanetell of Aguilar was born in Trinidad, Colorado in March 1892 as Emma Oberosler, daughter of a coal miner. He had moved to the U.S. and worked a few years, then went back to Germany to marry. He was a union supporter; their house was blown up as retribution for his union activities. At Sopris, the miners' wives united to stay in a boarding house, while their men were away at a march in Huerfano County. She recalls the strike in 1903, when her father was beaten. At age 12, her father fell ill and Emma began work doing laundry; he died in 2 years. Emma married in July of 1913, to a pit boss at the Forbes mine. He walked out when the company imported African-American strikebreakers. When the 1913 strike began in September, the company forced the Zanetells out of company housing. For the next 2.5 years, they lived in the tent colony at Forbes: stifling in summer heat and miserable in winter's snows. When people were gone to the funeral for her twins, the militia burned all the tents but hers. She was recovering, inside, and would've died -- but one militiaman threatened to kill the other if she were harmed. Her husband was blacklisted, but eventually worked at Ramey. She describes packing a hearty lunch in her husband's bucket for work. They view a photo of her friends and family in front of her tent. (There is a change of interviewers to Angela.) The Zanetells have been in their present home in Aguilar since 1916. Emma bore 13 children, 5 of whom died as children. During the coal strike of 1913-1914, her family lived in the tent colony near the Forbes mine in Colorado. There she lost 2 sets of twin children, who died shortly after their births in the tent. Company doctors would not come to help, because the miners had moved out of company housing. Doctors from town couldn't reach the tent colony, because of shooting along the route. Her children were delivered by other women in the tent colony. Dr. Beshoar, the UMW doctor, eventually came to her aid by crawling along the creek-bed to the Forbes colony. Company guards and militiamen burned the other tents, while the community was gone to Trinidad to bury her dead infants; Emma's was the only tent left standing -- because she was still inside, recovering. One militiaman threatened to kill the other if any harm came to her. After the strike, her family lived at Ramey and Aguilar, Colorado. For a while, she went to the cemetery daily to grieve for her dead children. Her husband worked at the Royal and Empire mines (where an explosion occurred and the mine whistle sounded the alarm to the families in town). Her 8 surviving children attended school in Aguilar and have each moved on to successful adult lives. The Great Depression was especially hard in 1939, but they always had plenty of food. The family rejoiced when her 4 sons returned home safely from World War II. She views photos and recalls the women's march in Trinidad, Mother Jones, and the family's tent at the Forbes colony.
Editing notes#1: JZ: transcript's first 29 pages NOT included in video; video continues another 12 minutes after transcript ends -- 18 Mar. 2014

Title#1: Interview with Mr. and Mrs. Steve Zoolakis
Subject#1$2: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Utah
Description#1: (no transcript for this interview) 10:00 -- conflicts with mine superintendents, before unionization 20:00 -- describes hand loading coal in early coal mines 28:14 -- Mrs. Zoolakis speaking 30:00 -- relations between Greeks and Mormons in this area 40:00 -- she describes touring a coal mine 42:20 -- Mr. Zoolakis re-joins conversation 50:00 -- discussing his brother's problems after mine injury and conflict with the law 60:00 -- discussing other old-timers in the area who might recall early coal mining
Description#2: This 80 year-old, Greek-American miner followed a cousin to America, after three of his brothers were killed in wars with the Turks. He describes early disputes in the coal mines, before unionization, and strike violence at the Hiawatha Mine. Despite being black-listed, Zoolakis remained in the UMWA union since 1922. Earning only $3.15 for an 8-hour day, he still managed to send money to his family in Greece. In the early days, he was hand-loading coal for only 27 cents/ton, up to 18 tons/day. He came to Utah, became a U.S. citizen, and raised 3 sons (none of whom followed into the mines). He worked 49 years and retired from US Steel. In mines, he worked as a helper (assisting with the coal mining machines). There were a couple of hundred other Greeks in the Columbia, Utah area. He suffers from some lung problems and knee pain (due to working in "low coal"). He also worked the Castle Gate coal mines. Mrs. Zoolakis was born in Greece also, grew up in Sunnside (Utah), and met her husband in America. Years ago, there were many nationalities in the area, but few conflicts among the diversity community. She reports that people now tend to stick more with their own kind, and that Mormons are more distant with their Gentile neighbors. She proudly describes her 3 sons' careers and families. Of 75 families living in Columbia, all but 2 children got post-secondary education. She worked as a nurse's aide and LPN (in the Kaiser Permanente hospital in Dragerton, Utah), to help put their sons thru school. All 3 sons have master's degrees. Her husband worked double shifts in the mine during WWII. She recalls that during the war, there was good money for a short while; soon, the mines began to decline and there were fewer jobs. She worked as an occupational nurse, conducting pre- and post-employment checks for miners. She remembers that 375 men were laid off at one time, and many left the area. Now, she notices some new hiring, as the demand for coal returns. As preparation for her work, she toured a coal mine and found it to be cold and scary. Mr. Zoolakis re-joins the conversation, and both discuss accidents in the mines, such as huge coal chunks crushing a miner. The couple describe "bounces" -- unexpected movements of coal within the mines. When fatalities occurred in mining accidents, the mine foreman and a doctor would notify families at home. Zoolakis's brother was injured in the mine, leading to a succession of other problems and conflicts with the law. These extended internationally to battles during WWI in Crete against the Turks. Zoolakis relates what he knew of a fellow Greek, Louis Tikas from the Ludlow strike; Zoolakis claims than the militia offered Tikas $30,000 to leave the strike. The couple describe strikes in their area of Utah -- not in 1933, but in 1937, lasting for 9 months. They received some food commodities, which they supplemented by hunting rabbits and deer. The UMWA was finally recognized by mine operators in 1937. They mention other old-timers in the area who might recall the early coal-mining era. They recall their earlier struggles for mine safety, shorter work-days, and union representation.

Part of Little Mexico before 1900 in Pueblo. It was last of south Santa Fe Ave., along Kelly Ave. Behind is goat Hill, later settled by Italians. The emmigrants from Italy & Mexico worked in the Pueblo smelters. Each had its own outhouse, dog, goat & sometimes a cow. The baking was done in the beehive shaped adobe outdoor ovens. Coals wree burned in the oven and then raked out. The bread of pastries were place in the oven by long-handled paddles. The single opening was covered and the retained heat baked the bread, usually made into large round crusted rolls. The northease from the D&RG railraod tracks.

Title#1: Erie coal miners: memories and thoughts
Subject#5: Quality of life -- United States -- History
Description#1: A group of seniors talk about their coal mining lives from around 1917 on. Most began working at age 12 or 14 and continued for some 35 years, moving from place to place, wherever jobs were. They recall 2-mile walks to the mine, 10-hour work days in dust-filled shafts, and low wages. They believe the well-being of the mining mules was of more concern than their own. There is brief talk about the Ludlow Massacre. Later, when the "continuous miner" machines were brought in, miners were laid off. Much of Colorado coal is 500 ft. underground, and they discuss strip mining, which is cheaper, even with the additional land reclamation costs. They feel that nuclear power produces more pollution but burning coal could be made to burn cleaner. They speak about Black Lung compensation and look back on the history of strikes in Colorado beginning in 1893.
Editing notes#1: CAH: no video

Title#1: Interview with High School students in Paonia, Colorado
Description#1: Discussion among the group: could the government takeover a mine, in order to force acceptance of a contract? The class doubt that troops have ever been sent into a coal mine. Then follows discussion of the non-union status of a new mine (Westmoreland), where the union is picketing to seek recognition. The group doubt that the facility will unionize, as the pay and benefits are already good. There have been minor incidents of vandalism, but even the picketers have cooperated with the management to clean up afterwards. The members mention the complexity of the proposed contract, and they draw distinctions between eastern vs. western coal mines. Some youngsters complain about boredom in this small town. There are remarks about the rate of growth (22% increase in population from 1974-1978). A recent bond issue was defeated, perhaps because much of the voting population were retirees on fixed incomes and feared increased taxes. The group feel that there has been modest increase in local jobs, but not so much as in Craig or Hayden, Colorado. There has been some local resistance to growth and concern about new growth in floodplains. Conversely, some residents complain that about a lack of shops or recreation choices. The interviewer queries the audience about major mine disasters nearby: they recall that in the Somerset mine, 4 miners were killed in a cave-in in 1969. After high school most girls leave the area, while some boys stay to work in the mines. Summer work is difficult to get. They discuss the first woman miner in the area: there was initial resistance (especially from older miners who considered women in the mine as bad luck) but more acceptance now. Most of this audience wouldn't want to work that hard, under those difficult/dangerous conditions. Members discuss plans after high school graduation: most plan on college, outside the area. Many guys return to the area and work in the mines, after trying college, because of the good pay. There's mention of working as miner vs. as a "company man": there seems to be less strife between groups here than in more entrenched communities. There has been some migration from Crested Butte, after mines closed there. Some families were originally Yugoslav or Austrian. Residents report some resentment of the impact of large construction crews, who briefly move into an area, make a lot of demands upon it, but then leave. There are conflicts with some "environmentalists", but there are also legitimate, local concerns about the environmental impact of Westmoreland's mining operations. The term "newcomers" is used broadly here: many long-time residents are still called that. There are concerns about rapid growth in the area, demands upon a limited water supply, and the need for zoning and land regulations. Some residents voice specific concerns about "trailer houses".
Editing notes#1: CAH: Pages 1-18 are 35:45 to 1:03:00(end) of Media Class video.

Title#1: Interview with the Moffat County Sheriff.
Description#1: Since coal development in this area began in 1969, changes have included drastic increases in real estate prices, especially in Craig. The Sheriff moved here from New Jersey about 7 years ago and still feels like a "newcomer". Newcomers have difficulty finding a place to live, but the economy is thriving and skilled workers are in high demand. Crime has also increased, with a 3- to 4-fold increase in civil actions by the Sheriff's office. The Sheriff disputes claims of high rates of juvenile delinquency and also feels the area's drug usage is typical of the nation's. Recreational opportunities for young people are limited. The Sheriff agrees there are some problems with transient workers, but feels they are not out of proportion. Newcomers and long-term residents often conflict. The newcomers might have good suggestions to address impact, as they've often seen such problems before. Development has been so recent that local politics have not yet been affected. However, a recent school bond issue failed, perhaps because it wasn't promoted well in this conservative county. Rapid economic development now offers jobs to recent graduates, who in the past would've left the area to find work. Long-term residents worry that they will end up paying for expensive new infrastructure, after the boom ends and temporary personnel have left. There was consideration of an expanded law enforcement facility, but it's not yet progressed. Currently they lack any facility for the mentally ill; those people are transferred by car to Pueblo. They also lack a juvenile facility, any kind of foster care, or a detoxification center. The jail lacks an exercise yard, and the crowded court docket means that inmates charged with a felony may wait for months before trial. The Sheriff anticipates another 6-8 years of growth before current mine construction is completed. Just one subdivision of mine-related housing equals 50% of Craig's population a few years ago. New churches are forming -- as are new drinking establishments. There has been rapid turnover in law enforcement personnel, statewide. He has retrained 2 women employees as jailors, who are doing well.
Editing notes#1: JZ: probable range of interview date based on pp. 2, 13; no video yet found for this transcript; 24 Mar. 2014

Subject#1$6: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: Picketers present anecdotes about harassment of employees and unsafe mine conditions. They recollect the antics of mules, used in the mines long ago. They wonder about recent union activities in Trinidad and Aguilar. They also complain about changes in the union's publication and leadership. Picketers had then been on strike for more than 90 days. They speculate about Pres. Carter's future actions on the strike. The miners wonder what they rest of the nation expects and insist that strikers' goal is retention of benefits. They discuss their earlier work in various mines across the country and share anecdotes about threats of violence to the picketers.
Editing notes#1: JZ

Title#1: Untitled interview: several retired miners discuss the Redstone and other coal mines.
Subject#1$3: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: Black lung disease follows the levels of dust in coal mines, which in turn relates to mechanization in the mines. Measures to suppress dust can succeed, but require investment by the owners. Compensation for affected miners is funded by the mine operators. They discuss unionization in coal mines of the West: some mines remain non-union by paying high wages and bonuses. Other union mines avoid the UMWA by organizing with operating engineers, etc. New mines are discussed, including their effects on nearby hot springs. The mines are influenced by the type of coal and by coking coal markets. Coal mining can cause a "bump" or "bounce" effect on surrounding geology. They also discuss "long haul" [long wall?] and continuous mining machines and other changes in mining over the last 40 years. All agreed that miners need to be trained on new equipment and that young miners need to be recruited into the union. The future of UMWA depends upon younger and non-union miners: many of these fear crime and corruption in the union. They discuss the frequent strikes earlier in their careers, without any strike benefits.
Editing notes#1: JZ: no video yet found for this transcript. 24 Mar. 2014

At the mine entrance they find signs of recent digging and assume people who needed heating coal came to find some here. One miner finds an old sprag, which is used for stopping coal cars. They go back to the cars. Then they are at Turner Mine and there are images of buildings, train tracks, and coal cars as well as shots inside building with gauges and equipment still in place. Ambient, casual talk or no audio throughout video.

Title#1: La Veta Museum plus historic pictures, saloon, UMWA flag
Subject#1$2: Coal miners -- Labor unions -- Colorado -- History -- 20th Century
Description#1: Video footage of the La Veta Museum, La Veta, Colorado. Footage includes a tour of the antique items from the last 200 years in the mining town. Phonograph machine, wooden spinning wheel, antique record player with a hand crank, antique fire heated iron, oil lamp, and a number of black and white photographs of people and an old certificate are all portrayed in the video. The final footage shows a flag for the United Mine Workers Local Union for Oak View, Colorado (which is now a ghost town but was once the town that served Oakdale Mine).

Title#1: Snow scenes plus Rocky Mountain News on Columbine Massacre
Subject#1$4: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: Video footage of snow scenes, power lines, wildflowers, plants poking through the snow, long-needled evergreen trees. Footage then cuts to newspaper clippings from the Rocky Mountain News pertaining to the Columbine Massacre in Serene, CO. Articles discuss the massacre itself, listing the names of the men who died, and also show photos of the families of the men who were killed, the factory where the event took place, and the key players in the horrible bloodbath.

Subject#1$2: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: First footage shows a man interviewing a coal miner in front of a pay phone booth, but there is sporadic sound. Next the film is focused on a coal miner and interviewer who are discussing the UMW (United Mine Workers) strike and contract which was taking place at the time of the filming. They introduce the miner as Bill Morgan, he later says he does electrician work at the mine nearby. He discusses his observations on labor strikes and the struggle for medical and death benefits, and after some banter back and forth with some other miners walking in and around the restaurant, another coal mine worker (he mentions he is technically a carpenter) , who they call "Pete" enters the conversation and sits with the men. The increased productivity in the mines, and the changes that have occurred with the passage of decades is discussed briefly, then they state that despite the improvement in working conditions and pay, they still didn't pressure their children to become coal miners because they wanted a better life for them. One miner states that his oldest son worked briefly in the mine but he now teaches classes, and his youngest son became a miner, but not because he was encouraged by Bill Morgan. Both men agree that the Union hasn't had great leadership since the death of John L. Lewis. The miners do concede that years ago, they had to "dig trench" or "put up fence" to supplement the irregular hours of the mine in order to make ends meet, and the company store got all of the mining money back for the company in the form of supplies and food. "Pete" tells the interviewers that the "reporting" of the strike issues isn't complete, and the reporters tell the story that they want to tell, so no matter what the miners tell them about the truth of the labor strike, the reality of the situation is never given to the people, so the people just think about how the coal shortage is affecting them, but they don't think about what the miners to through to get them that coal.

Title#1: Striking coal miners in Paonia, Colorado, 1978 (pt. 1 of 2)
Subject#2: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: 00:00 Striking miners talk among themselves 10:00 Talk about members who want to go back to work 20:00 Talk about grazing sheep 30:00 Multiple conversations 40:00 Oil companies prefer atomic energy becasue they control Uranium 50:00 Striking miners by the side of the road, low audio 60:00 Striking miners by the side of the road, low audio 1:03:45 End
Description#2: Striking miners, congregate in a make-shift hut, discussing strike and union issues. Multiple conversations go on most of the time. They talk about snow fall, fights, and grazing sheep. A miner says he worked in one mine under three different companies and stresses the importance of a reliable pension fund system. In Westmoreland mine the bosses were issued guns by the company, but these were withdrawn when word got out to the public. They talk about how miners are now fighting both coal and oil companies. One miner explains that the energy crisis was created to benefit the rich. If there really were a shortage, we would develop long-lasting, high-mileage cars, but the economy is based on wastefulness and profits. Footage of miners standing outside the hut talking, with mountain scenery behind them, makes up the rest of the video.
Editing notes#1: CAH: 32:15 to 38:00 is p.12-15 of Picket2 transcript. No transcript for the rest of the video.

Subject#2: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Subject#7: Labor movement -- United States -- History -- 20th century
Description#1: The high school media class continues, discussing small town growth as new employers arrive. Highways are built, trailer parks appear, and retail business increase. The main concern, however, is the limited supply of water in the region. The UMWA local holds a special meeting to discuss a contract offer. An article is read aloud, explaining the current labor dispute. Another article is read, criticizing a P&M settlement, which local unions are being pressured to accept or face a government injunction. Union leaders admit to having missed an important section that makes the new contract (P&M) identical to what was previously voted down (BCOA offer). A discussion follows what they would be able to negotiate for and vote on in the future. The miners are worried about their pension fund and benefits. What the majority opposes is separate, local contracts in a "divide and rule" fashion and some speak out for continuing the strike.

Title#1: Portal Party (pt. 2 of 2) and interview with striking miners
Description#1: 00:00 Portal party at the saloon 10:00 Pause in the music, people are talking, children playing 20:00 The bar of te saloon, man denounces scabs 30:00 Miner interviews begin 40:00 Somerset was a steady mine until oil started being used 50:00 Did the kids stay in the area when they grew up? 60:00 The company weighman cheated the miners with every car 1:04:00 End
Description#2: The multi-generational party continues at a saloon with live music and dancing. An older man plays a Wurlitzer organ and a younger man plays electric guitar and sings. Then striking miners are interviewed. They feel that the past decades were the good days. Though life was hard, people were more satisfied. They also stuck together more and helped each other. Today life is dominated by consumer goods. Then families went into debt to survive the summer months and they had they very little. Today people have a lot but debt keeps piling up. They also talk about coal qualities, tools they needed to purchase, and drilling methods. Much of their day was spent on dead work, for which they didn't get paid, i.e., timbering, laying tracks, and picking rock out of the coal.
Editing notes#1: CAH: no transcript for this video

Title#1: Striking coal miners in Paonia, Colorado, 1978 (pt. 2 of 2)
Subject#2: Strikes and lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: Striking miners, congregate in a make-shift hut, discussing strike and union issues. They recall that boys as young as ten worked in the mine, if they had someone to train them, usually their father or uncle. Before the union was established, miners did not get paid for mine preparation work and families received nothing when a miner died in the mine. They talk about how they survived during the Depression. Even now, miners have ranches, farms and orchards to make ends meet. Multiple conversations go on about working for many companies, Medicare, and enduring the strike. Then the video has street scenes of Paonia and the last 2 1/2 minutes shots of the Bowie Mine.
Description#2: 00:00 Striking miners talk abong themselves 10:00 Indians being cheated out of their coal fields by the U.S. Government 20:00 A trailer caved in from snow masses in the mountains 30:00 Miner states young miners are right behind them, supporting the strike 40:00 Multiple conversations among the miners 50:00 Street scenes in Paonia 60:00 End

Title#1: Sudar's Mine, Sunset, Fire, Moon (Walsenburg, Colo.)
Description#1: Film footage shows an abandoned mine and other rural areas, most likely Colorado. The title of the video is Sudars Mine, which has also been known as Calumet No.2, Delcarbon, Brennan, and Little Turner mine. At one point the mine was owned by the Sudars brothers. After the mine building footage concludes, there is footage of trees and sky, then a sunset followed by footage of a fire burning, then footage of the moon.

Subject#1$5: Strikes and Lockouts -- Coal mining -- Colorado
Description#1: Video exhibits a gathering of miners and ex-miners in Carbondale, CO. The interviewers have just showed a program on a screen about the history of mining and they ask the crowd for opinions about the accuracy of the program. The miners then describe their own experiences with mining, including where they have worked in their long careers, how much they were paid when they began, and what kind of technology (or lack thereof) was available when they started mining. The miners describe the conditions in the mines, especially the dust problem, and Black Lung, and what mining companies could do to make the conditions better, such as add exhaust fans and increase moisture in the mines. The miners also discuss the politics behind unions and strikes in regards to their own lives. The interviewers ask the miners about the generational differences between young, current miners and the old miners of the past, and how technology has improved the working conditions and productivity of the mines. The miners also give opinion about what they think the future of mining will be. The meeting concludes with friendly small talk.
